pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.origin: USGS Alaska Science Center Walrus Research Program
citeinfo.title: Understanding and Forecasting the Response of Pacific Walrus Populations to a Diminishing Sea Ice Environment

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

descript.abstract: We summarize available information on Pacific walrus haulouts from available reports, interviews with coastal residents and aviators, and personal observations of the authors. We provide this in the form of a georeferenced database that may be queried and displayed with standard geographic information system and database management software. The database contains 150 records of Pacific walrus haulouts, with a summary of basic characteristics on maximum haulout size, age-sex composition, season of use, and decade of most recent use. Citations to reports are provided as a bibliographic database.
descript.purpose: These data were compiled to provide resource managers with a consolidated and comprehensive source of information about location, history and summary characteristics of reported Pacific walrus haulouts throughout their range.
descript.supplinf: The database consists of a set of interrelated digital files, including the geographic representation of the haulouts and a bibliographic database of the reports cited for each haulout record. The georeferenced component of the database is provided in two digitally accessible forms: one intended for display and query in a Geographic Information System (GIS), and another for display and query in a virtual globe. The form of the database intended for display and query in a GIS is provided in two file formats: a tabular comma separated value (CSV) file (PacificWalrusHauloutDatabase.csv) and a shape file (PacificWalrusHauloutsDatabaseLinearFeatures.shp). The CSV file is encoded using the UTF-8 character encoding and can include all fields of the database, including the Cyrillic script field containing Russian language names of the haulouts. The shape file contains a geographic representation of spatial lines representing haulouts that are depicted as linear features. Linear features contained in the shape file may be linked back to the full record of the haulout contained within the CSV file based on a key field. The form of the database intended for display and query in a virtual globe is provided as a single keyhole markup language (KML) file (PacificWalrusHauloutDatabase.kml) that contains all points and linear features, including the Cyrillic script field with the Russian language names of the haulouts. The KML file can be viewed in a virtual globe such as Google Earth (http://www.google.com/earth/), Marble (http://marble.kde.org/), or World Wind (http://worldwind.arc.nasa.gov/java/). The bibliographic component of the database (the file PacificWalrusHauloutDatabaseBibliography_DS.RIS) provides a listing of all reports cited in the database. This machine readable bibliographic data file is a complete copy of the citations listed in appendix A of the summary report.

spdom.descgeog: The coasts of the Bering, Chukchi, southern Beaufort, and eastern East Siberian Seas

citeinfo.title: Üeberblick der Säugethiere nach ihrer Vertheilung über die Welttheile. [A review of mammal distribution on a world basis]

taxonsys.taxonpro: Taxonomy of the study species was accepted from the available reports, personal communications and personal observations with the assurance that the only walrus sub-species observed to date within the study area is the Pacific walrus. Aerial observations of Pacific walrus coastal haulouts were only accepted if the observers clearly indicated that the observations could not be confused with coastal haulouts of sea lions, or harbor and ice seals.
taxonsys.taxoncom: Polar bears are easily distinguishable from other species by physical characteristics and habitat use patterns. In most cases, species was confirmed genetically.

idinfo.useconst: It is requested that the authors and the USGS Alaska Science Center be cited for any subsequent publications that reference this dataset. It is strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data to evaluate data set limitations, restrictions or intended use. It is the responsibility of the user to use the data appropriately and consistent with the limitations of the data in general and these data in particular.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey Alaska Science Center

idinfo.datacred: Nikita Platonov, Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution, Russian Academy of Sciences

citeinfo.title: Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database, 1852–2016—Background Report

attracc.attraccr: Please refer to the Open File Report (Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database, 1852–2016—Background Report referenced in the cross-reference section of this metadata report) for details on the data collection and compilation effort.

dataqual.logic: Please refer to the Open File Report (Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database, 1852–2016—Background Report referenced in the cross-reference section of this metadata report) for details on the data collection and compilation effort.
dataqual.complete: Pacific walrus haulouts information was summarized from available reports, interviews with coastal residents and aviators, and personal observations of the authors. This dataset contains a summary of basic characteristics on maximum haulout size, age-sex composition, season of use, and decade of most recent use.

horizpa.horizpar: We assigned a geographic location to each haulout based on available data sources, and adjusted the location based on publicly available geo-referenced imagery (Digital Globe, Longmont, Colorado, USA, viewed through the virtual digital globe geographical information system Google Earth TM ). Spatial accuracy varies among the haulout records, but is generally within 5 kilometers of the actual reported haulout location.

method.methdesc: Data on Pacific haulout locations and their historical use was compiled from available data sources and entered into a Microsoft Access database.

procstep.procdesc: We exported a comma separated value file encoded in UTF-8 that contained all fields within the database. We used the plotKML contributed package in r (plotKML v 0.5-6; http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/plotKML accessed 16 April 2016) to construct a Keyhole Markup Language file from the database with all fields including the Cyrillic script field containing the Russian language names of the haulout locations. We used the ESRI software ArcGIS (v 10.1) to digitize coastal linear features represented haulouts that occurred along an extended coastline.

enttyp.enttypd: Comma separated value UTF-8 tabulation. This file contains all fields of the database in tabular format, including both the Latin script and the Cyrillic script fields of the database. Each record represents a single haulout with details on its geography, history and summary characteristics.
enttyp.enttypds: The data contents are defined by USGS. The data structure follows Shafranovich (2005). Shafranovich, Y. (2005). Common Format and MIME Type for Comma-Separated Values (CSV) Files. The Internet Society, Network Working Group 4180 (https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4180)

enttyp.enttypd: Keyhole Markup Language file containing all fields of the database in tabular format, including the Cyrillic script field (Русскоеназвание) that contains the Russian language name of the haulout. Each record represents a single haulout with details on it's geography, history and summary characteristics. Each haulout is represented as a point, and haulouts that are represented as linear features are also represented with a linear feature within this file.

enttyp.enttypd: Machine readable bibliography of the reports cited in the Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database. This bibliography contains 151 citations for reports cited in the Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database. Within the Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database each haulout record includes a narrative summary of reports that mention the haulout along with citations to the reports listed in the bibliography. This machine readable bibliography is provided to enable the use of the biobliography records in bibliographic managment software; and is a complete copy of the bibliography provided as appendix A to the open file report (USGS OFR 2016-110, http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ofr20161108). The RIS file format was developed by Research Information Systems, which produced the bibliographic management software Refman, and was later acquired by Thomson ISI ResearchSoft. The file format and encoding specification for the RIS file is available from Thomson Reuters at http://refman.com/support/risformat_intro.asp and also available through Wikipedia at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RIS_(file_format).

overview.eaover: The database consists of a set of interrelated digital files (PacificWalrusHauloutDatabase.csv, PacificWalrusHauloutsDatabaseLinearFeatures.shp, PacificWalrusHauloutDatabase.KML, and PacificWalrusHauloutDatabaseBibliography_DS.RIS). The georeferenced component of the database is provided in two digitally accessible forms: one intended for display and query in a Geographic Information System (GIS), and another for display and query in a virtual globe. The form of the database intended for display and query in a GIS is provided in two file formats: a tabular comma separated value or CSV file (PacificWalrusHauloutDatabase.csv) and a shape file (PacificWalrusHauloutsDatabaseLinearFeatures.shp). The CSV file is encoded using the UTF-8 character encoding and can include all fields of the database, including the Cyrillic script field containing Russian language names of the haulouts. The shape file contains a geographic representation of spatial lines representing haulouts that are depicted as linear features. Linear features contained in the shape file may be linked back to the full record of the haulout contained within the CSV file based on a key field. The form of the database intended for display and query in a virtual globe is provided as a single keyhole markup language or KML file (PacificWalrusHauloutDatabase.KML) that contains all points and linear features, including he Cyrillic script field with the Russian language names of the haulouts. The KML file can be viewed in a virtual globe such as Google Earth (http://www.google.com/earth/), Marble (http://marble.kde.org/), or World Wind (http://worldwind.arc.nasa.gov/java/). In addition to the haulout geographic database files, we provided a machine-readable bibliographic file that is a full copy of the references cited in the database (n = 151, PacificWalrusHauloutDatabaseBibliography_DS.RIS). Bibliographic data management software is required to display and manipulate the citations in the machine readable bibliographic file. However, a full listing of these references is provided in a standard bibliographic listing format in Appendix A of the USGS Open File Report (USGS OFR 2016-110, http://dx.doi.org/10.3133/ofr20161108).

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

distinfo.resdesc: CSV and KML of the U.S. Geological Survey Pacific Walrus Coastal Haulout Database.
distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
